awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Self-healing Power Electronics for Urban Air Mobility Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to increase safety and reduce weight and redundancies for many vehicular systems and electronic devices. This project will also enhance autonomous systems integration in terms of diagnostics and enable reconfiguration for a variety of safety-critical applications. The proposed self-healing, fault-tolerant, power electronics have a large market beyond Urban Air Mobility (UAM) applications and can be implemented in a wide range of markets from transportation, to space/aerospace, biomedical devices, and microgrids. The ability of power electronics to self-diagnose faults, engage redundancy, reconfigure, and maintain operation will be fundamental in such safety-critical applications.  This project will initially be applied to the safest and most sustainable Urban Air Mobility vehicles of the future offering best-in-class user experiences that can drastically improve the lives of U.S. citizens by reducing travel time with improved safety.  Potential applications and use cases include on-demand air taxis, airport shuttles, personal air vehicles, last-mile delivery, air ambulance, military applications, and rescue missions. 

The goal of the proposed effort is to create self-healing, high-power-density, reconfigurable, and modular power electronic converters (dc/ac inverters, dc/dc converters, and ac/dc battery chargers) and architectures for Urban Air Mobility (UAM) applications. The main technical objective of this project is to improve fault tolerance in the event of battery module or motor failure in the presence of several other healthy batteries and propulsion motors. The second objective is to explore machine learning techniques in dc/ac inverter and ac/dc charger applications.  The third and final objective for this project is to study the impact of the proposed self-healing modular power electronics architecture on battery state-of-charge, life, and propulsion system performance in a safety-critical UAM application. Reliability models that consider healthy and various reconfigured system architectures will be established.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Phase 1 of this project was successfully completed to achieve a high-power-density and self-healing multipurpose ac/dc converter for aerospace applications. The converter can be implemented in multi-phase ac/dc applications for propulsion, or in dc/dc battery-interfacing applications. It is designed for bidirectional energy flow and serves as a fundamental building block for fault-tolerant aerospace power conversion. The proposed design is enabled by SiC technology and a novel active neutral point clamp (ANPC) topology that can achieve over 98% efficiency over a wide load range, in addition to a 15 kW/liter air-cooled power density that can extrapolate to over 150 kW/liter with liquid cooling. Self-healing is enabled by an artificial neural network that achieves over 89% fault diagnosis accuracy for open- and short-circuit faults in four SiC device pairs using experimental sensor signals, without being impacted by noise and electromagnetic interference. All faults are diagnosed in less than 200 ms, thus enabling reconfiguration of the proposed converter to maintain safe operation after fault occurrence by isolating the faulty device from the circuit.

The proposed converter enables reliable and long-life operation of batteries and propulsion motors in addition to safe take-off, cruising, and landing capability. This is critical for the future of personal air mobility and can be capitalized upon in other applications such as unmanned water vehicles, unmanned ground vehicles, safety-critical biomedical equipment, and mission-critical defense applications.

Phase II will enable further increase in power density to achieve 150 kW/liter with liquid cooling, implement the proposed converter in ac/dc propulsion applications, and implement it in dc/dc battery interfacing applications. Thermal models will be developed in Phase II in addition to full self-healing operation in both propulsion and battery interfacing. A lab-scale eVTOL will be implemented to demonstrate low-altitude mid-flight self-healing capability to ensure safe take-off, cruising, and landing under power semiconductor device failures. A solid commercialization plan will be implemented along with plans for production beyond Phases II and III of the project.

 


Last Modified: 02/16/2025
Modified by: Jacob M Matly
